data.title: Support for Physx 3.3.2 with VS 2010
data.body:
This one is a tricky one, starting with Physx 3.3.2 NVidia are now shipping separate dll/lib for different versions of Visual Studio. This PR adds support for VS 2010 (which technically is the max version project gen supports) but if you are using a later version of VS it won't compile (you need the matching versions). You would need to open up physx3.inc file and change "vc10" to whatever version you are using (currently NVidia only support vc9/10/11)

I'm really not sure what to do about this?

data.title: Implementing crunch (DXT compression library) - replaces 'squish'.
data.body: At the moment this implementation uses fastest compression method, but so far it looks like its better than fastest squish (at least for terrain basemaps).

data.title: WaterBlock rotation
data.body:
Currently when you rotate a WaterBlock you will get incorrect values returned from WaterBlock::getWaterCoverage because the overlap test is performed with a AABB when it needs a OBB. This will cause water sounds and underwater caustics etc to be enabled at the wrong places.

 I do have a fix in our DeadlyMatter build so i will pass it on. Just putting this up as a reminder in case i forget :)

data.title: feature request- maximize storage/retrieval
data.body:
https://github.com/GarageGames/Torque3D/blob/3082bb3adc75134dc4cba2e1787b8ec838771ed5/Engine/source/gui/core/guiCanvas.cpp#L2588 can be used via console to maximize the application window. (Though in windows at least, the script is not executed by doubletapping the form window)

$pref::video::somenewglobal would be automatically saved on application exit.

The request being passed along was to provide a method for storing and retrieving the window in a maximized state similar to how fullscreen is handled.

data.title: Added OpenGL module with some additions to the project generator

milestone.title: OpenGL3
milestone.description:
This milestone tracks the progress of adding an OpenGL rendering backend to the engine alongside the current DirectX backend, which is unfortunately the only backend of the abstracted GFX interface. This will allow OpenGL rendering on multiple platforms, but specifically OXS and Linux.

[Working branch.](https://github.com/BeamNG/Torque3D/tree/dev_linux_opengl)

data.body: Adds a Project Generator module for OpenGL. This required adding the ability to check Project Generator defines after they have been added. Note the PHP code here isn't verified, so I may be doing it wrong. Also note that it's not reliable - it's dependent on the order in which PG modules are executed, so you can only check for defines that have already been added.

data.title: An alternative to PathShape
data.body:
This is from http://www.garagegames.com/community/forums/viewthread/137542

I'm calling this resource WalkableShapes (I'm open to suggestions for better class names). It provides three classes that can be used in games. TSPathShape is a simple path following shape. TSAttachable builds on TSPathShape to add the ability for players to walk on the shape while it's moving. The script interface for this class is almost identical to the traditional PathShape. The setup is slightly different. Since the DataBlock has been eliminated, the shape file is set in the editor. The WalkableShape class is a simple shape object that players can walk on while it's moving. It provides no movement of it's own, but can be mounted to...Anything! So if you want to walk on the back of a flatbed truck, model the bed as a separate shape and mount it to the truck in game as a WalkableShape. It can be mounted to any shape that provides movement. There is a demo level included that has a platform-jumping mini-game and a Cheetah with a platform mounted to the roof where the turret normally mounts. You'll need two connections to try that though.

data.title: Asset downloader
data.body:
This PR provides a mechanism for synchronizing files between the client and the server.
It does allow users to upload content to the server if the file transfer connection is left connected.
The code is implemented using the TCPObject as the base class.  I have taken the liberty to make a couple of TCPObject's functions virtual so I could overload them for binary transfer.
I also modified fileSystemFunctions.cpp and took the body of code out each of the defineconsolefunctions and put them in a function and wrapped all the functions inside a namespace.  I also added a header file which can be included so that programmers are able to access those functions from anywhere in the code base.
Since the FileXfer occurs over TCP,  I am able to use the same port which is used for the game.  This is because T3D runs its network over UDP and this PR is implemented over tcp.

You are able to specify the files you want to include for download by editing the core/Scripts/server/fileXferServer.cs file.

Two ways of adding files to be available for download:

LoadPath (Pattern, Recursive, multiMatch, Verbose) and works just like the FindFiles file searching.
LoadFile (filename) - It will check if the file exists, if it exists it will add it to the download.

Let me know if you find any errors.

Vince Gee
Winterleafentertainment.com

data.title: TypeBool should serialize to boolean
data.body: [This line](https://github.com/GarageGames/Torque3D/blob/69838bdc8c9bc055b9b1ae76f42b0f28d2a33909/Engine/source/console/consoleTypes.cpp#L472) serializes boolean types as `"1"` and `"0"`. Should that be changed to `"true"` and `"false"`?

data.title: Navmesh saving doesn't use filesystem abstraction
data.body: Instead it just calls C++ file IO functions directly. Bad Daniel. Specifically, [here](https://github.com/GarageGames/Torque3D/blob/development/Engine/source/navigation/navMesh.cpp#L817) and [here](https://github.com/GarageGames/Torque3D/blob/development/Engine/source/navigation/navMesh.cpp#L891).
